Journal.Title: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
Journal.ISOAbbreviation: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A

Article.ArticleTitle: Anoxic photogeochemical oxidation of manganese carbonate yields manganese oxide.

AbstractText: The oxidation states of manganese minerals in the geological record have been interpreted as proxies for the evolution of molecular oxygen in the Archean eon. Here we report that an Archean manganese mineral, rhodochrosite (MnCO<sub>3</sub>), can be photochemically oxidized by light under anoxic, abiotic conditions. Rhodochrosite has a calculated bandgap of about 5.4 eV, corresponding to light energy centering around 230 nm. Light at that wavelength would have been present on Earth's surface in the Archean, prior to the formation of stratospheric ozone. We show experimentally that the photooxidation of rhodochrosite in suspension with light centered at 230 nm produced H<sub>2</sub> gas and manganite (γ-MnOOH) with an apparent quantum yield of 1.37 × 10<sup>-3</sup> moles hydrogen per moles incident photons. Our results suggest that manganese oxides could have formed abiotically on the surface in shallow waters and on continents during the Archean eon in the absence of molecular oxygen.
